div1.head: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Henry Rose Carter, December 22, 1924
div1.opener:
Book
Frost.
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
SCHOOL OF HYGIENE AND PUBLIC HEALTH
310-312 WEST MONUMENT STREET
BALTIMORE, MD. December 22, 1924.
DEPARTMENT OF EPIDEMIOLOGY AND
PUBLIC HEALTH ADMINISTRATION
Dr. H. R. Carter,
2122 California Street,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I am at last returning your manuscripts with a
memorandum of notes which are much too lengthy for their
insignificant import.

In reviewing your manuscript I have taken it
for granted that it has not yet been finally edited for
publication and have accordingly made no note of such
minor matters as typographical errors, etc. which will
readily be checked up in the final editing.

As regards the epidemiological argument I felt
sure before seeing the manuscript, as I still feel, that
your reasoning would be straighter and your conclusions more
precise and conservative than mine, so that while I have
tried to examine the argument critically it has been with
no thought that I could find any fault with your conclu-
sions or could make any suggestions for modifying them.
It has seemed to me that any service which I might be able
to render would be solely in letting you know how readily
your evidence would be grasped and your argument followed
by one who, like myself, starts in with only a limited know-
ledge of the facts. Therefore, in the first part of my
memorandum I have made a few notes and suggestions which
have nothing to do with the validity of your argument but
relate only to making it a little easier to follow. However,
I do not consider these suggestions of any importance and
if they would involve any considerable amount of work on
your part which would delay completion of the history,
I think it would be much better to disregard them entirely.
The rest of my notes, referring to the argument itself, are
merely to let you know how it impresses me, that is, to
show you how nearly I may have grasped or failed to grasp
the significance of your facts. If these notes have any
value at all to you it will be chiefly to show you how
far a reasonably intelligent person previously unfamiliar
with the facts may be expected to assimilate them after
Dr. Carter
-2-
12-22-24
a fairly careful reading.

My notes, having been written at odd times and
somewhat hurriedly, are not in precise language, so that
I am expecting you to understand what I mean rather than
precisely what I say in passages which are ambiguous or
incomplete. If you find from my notes that I have been
able to follow your arguments with fair directness I think
you may be sure that the average reader who is sincerely
interested and open-minded will also follow them. If I
have misinterpreted them or overlooked the salient points
I judge this will mean nothing except that you will have
to depend for full understanding upon those who will read
it more keenly than I have been able to do.

It has been many a day since I have regardedenjoyed any
reading so much. I do not know of anything with which
I can compare your manuscript except Snow's Monograph on
Cholera. Your work is equally to his in its reasoning and
greatly exceeds it in material. I shall be interested to
know what the African history shows, but as I have said
in my notes, I do not see how the facts from that side or
any other facts which may subsequently come to light can
have any other effect than to confirm conclusions which
already seem inevitable.

I am still hoping to be able to get over to Wash-
ington before the New Year and to have a chance to see you.
It is, however, a little difficult, because I have less
business in Washington this year than in previous years;
and if one is fully occupied every day it is hard to find
opportunities for even short trips except under necessity.

Wishing you and Miss Laura a very happy Christmas
and a the New Year which will see your history completed
and ready for publication,
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, W. H. Frost. WHF:G
